thread.title: Filmmaker Loach hits back at Belgian premier in anti-Semitism row

title: Filmmaker Loach hits back at Belgian premier in anti-Semitism row
text:
April 26, 2018 / 7:44 PM / Updated 13 hours ago Filmmaker Loach hits back at Belgian premier in anti-Semitism row Reuters Staff 2 Min Read
BRUSSELS (Reuters) - British film director Ken Loach accused Belgium’s prime minister on Thursday of ignoring “flagrant breaches of international law” by Israel in a row over alleged anti-Semitism and the filmmaker’s long-time support of Palestinians. 70th Cannes Film Festival - Photocall for the 70th Anniversary of the festival - Cannes, France. 23/05/2017. Director Ken Loach poses for a family picture with former Cannes festival award winners. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe
Speaking after being awarded an honorary doctorate at one of Belgium’s leading universities, Loach said he was shocked that premier Charles Michel had chosen to criticise the institution for giving him the award.
“Now, he’s a lawyer, Mr. Michel ... Did he I wonder, ask about the breaches of international law committed by Israel? Did he ask about the illegal occupation of Palestinian lands?” said Loach, the 81-year-old director of 2016 Palme d’Or winner “I, Daniel Blake”.
Michel, 42, studied law at the Free University of Brussels and chided it on Wednesday for plans to award Loach an honorary doctorate. Loach denies accusations that his support for Palestinians is anti-Semitic.
In a speech on Wednesday at Brussels’ Grand Synagogue to mark the 70th anniversary of Israel’s foundation, Michel said: “No accommodation with anti-Semitism can be tolerated, whatever its form. And that also goes for my own alma mater.”
In a statement on Thursday, the European Jewish Congress called on the university to revoke its decision to honour Loach, saying he had “constantly undermined efforts to combat anti-Semitism in the UK”.
The dispute in Belgium comes as the British Labour Party under left-winger Jeremy Corbyn, for whom Loach has been a vocal supporter, is battling allegations of anti-Semitism.
(This story has been refiled to correct typos in first and third paragraphs.) Reporting by Natalie Rice; Editing by Alexandra Hudson
